title: What is the tone of the custom house from The Scarlet Letter? I need to write an analysis on it. - Quora

response.answer_text: Your best bet is to google good keywords (I used “scarlet letter hawthorne custom house” without the quote marks). The first site that popped up was sparknotes with a wonderful explanation. A few links later is cliffsnotes. The sparknotes site described the tone of the custom house this way: “This introduction provides a frame for the main narrative of The Scarlet Letter. The nameless narrator, who shares quite a few traits with the book’s author, takes a post as the “chief executive officer,” or surveyor, of the Salem Custom House. (“Customs” are the taxes paid on foreign imports into a country; a 'customhouse' is the building where these taxes are paid.) He finds the establishment to be a run-down place, situated on a rotting wharf in a half-finished building. His fellow workers mostly hold lifetime appointments secured by family connections. They are elderly and given to telling the same stories repeatedly. The narrator finds them to be generally incompetent and innocuously corrupt.” I didn't dig into sparknotes and cliffsnotes but am sure there is more description of that custom house and its tone. Also, check out the gradesaver site just below cliffsnotes.
